subject: Anon collects reverse Jew tax on short, asks about funding fees
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: A trader, confused but delighted by receiving funding fees on a short position, interprets it as 'turning the tables on the jews.' The thread provides explanations of funding fees, blending genuine financial education with prevalent anti-Semitic tropes and a conspiratorial worldview common on /biz/.
top_quote: I gotta be real with you, I don't really understand why funding fees exist other than to encourage people to throw more money in. Blogposts claim that funding fees are necessary for "price control" but the prices are all set by oracles, not by traders, so that is nonsense. Anyway, the long and short of it (haha) is that the funding rate depends on the ratio of longs to shorts. If a lot of people are longing on your exchange, then they'll be paying you funding fees and you'll earn interest on your short. Since perps markets tend to be bullish, that means usually shorters get paid. But sometimes certain assets get shorted to all hell which means they'll be the ones paying. So it depends a bit on the pair you're trading
image_analysis: The image is a dark, shadowy Pepe variant with wide, slightly worried eyes, conveying a sense of lurking, uncertainty, or dark humor.

assets.name: Funding Fees
assets.narrative: A mechanism in perpetual futures where one side (longs or shorts) pays the other, often misunderstood but can be a source of income.

assets.name: Cryptocurrency
assets.narrative: OP states crypto 'treated me very well' and he did this 'for the love of the game.'

assets.name: Leveraged Positions and Perpetuals Markets
assets.narrative: These are the financial vehicles where funding fees exist, allowing for potentially profitable income streams from fees.

assets.name: The Jews / The System

subject: Did the boomers have it worse than us in the 70s?
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: This thread debates whether the 1970s or the present day presents greater economic hardship, particularly focusing on inflation, wages, and cost of living. It rapidly devolves into a heated, often uncivil generational blame game, with strong anti-boomer sentiment attributing current woes to their era's policies and lifestyles.
top_quote:
>>61413115
>but just making her humble dish feels like a step down- not being able to eat out hurts how good you feel about your financial standing.
Literally not a single person I know feels this way. Stay at home wife making food for you is THE flex of our generation.
You must actually be a boomer, because not only are you clearly retarded with a maggoty brain, you have the same stupid standards as a boomer. You have no fucking clue how most people ages 18-35 actually feel because you're the one only observing the conspicuous consumption on your smart phone, because your stupid generation got hooked on TV and is even more obsessed with screens than we are.
image_analysis: The image is a Reddit screenshot from r/AskOldPeople asking "How did 1970s Great Inflation compare to 2020s inflation?" and features comments from older users detailing much higher inflation, interest rates (e.g., 18% mortgage), and gas shortages in the 1970s, implying those times were economically harder.

assets.name: Boomers
assets.narrative: They are accused of having destroyed society and lying about economic hardships in the 70s, often perceived as having benefited from real wage growth and cheaper assets despite facing high interest rates.

assets.name: Inflation
assets.narrative: Described as 'double-digit,' necessitating large COL adjustments, and causing gas shortages and high mortgage rates (up to 18%), which some argue was still easier to manage due to lower asset prices and higher wages relative to cost.

assets.name: Inflation
assets.narrative: Perceived as underestimated by official statistics ('falsified numbers') and causing real wage decline, making it harder to afford necessities like housing compared to the 70s.

assets.name: Wages
assets.narrative: Claims that 1970s workers saw significant annual wage increases (e.g., 7-10%) and higher real wages compared to current decades of real wage decline and stagnation.

assets.name: Housing Market
assets.narrative: 70s homes were significantly cheaper (e.g., $15k) and rapidly appreciated, even with high interest rates (18% mortgages), allowing for quicker payoff; modern housing prices are inflated relative to wages.

assets.name: Central Banking
assets.narrative: Implicated as a primary cause of economic problems, with some suggesting its abolition is necessary but impossible due to global powers.

assets.name: Gold
assets.narrative: Used as a benchmark to demonstrate the decline in real wages, showing that a machinist could buy significantly less gold with 10 hours of work in 2025 compared to 1975.

assets.name: Internet/Social Media
assets.narrative: Accused of creating unrealistic expectations and driving consumerism among younger generations, leading them to spend money on frivolous goods rather than saving.

subject: JUST 15 MORE YEARS LINK MARINES, HOLD THE LINE!
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: This thread captures the profound psychological struggle and tribalism within a long-term crypto community, specifically Chainlink holders. It exposes a mix of extreme conviction, denial, sunk-cost fallacy, and cult-like devotion, clashing with equally fervent and often mocking critics who highlight the asset's underperformance and the holders' perceived delusion.
top_quote: >>61423447 >He thinks LINK will do a 3x ATH The bull run doesn’t matter to stinkies. They are completely out of touch with the entire crypto market. They peaked in 2018 in terms of following trends and learning about new projects. After 2018, they could only process link in their minds. Truly a fascinating phenomenon that should be studied by experts. Never has an investor married their bags to the point of obsession and building their identities around their investment more than stinkies. It’s almost a unique case of Stockholm syndrome mixed with schizophrenia. When you bring up topics to stinkies such as “bull run” “crypto market” etc their mind goes blank, they don’t even process what you are saying. In their minds there is one thing and one thing only; Link and Sergei. Their warped minds will come up with endless grandiose scenarios to maintain their illusion that they are genius investors who are smarter than everyone else. They simultaneously hate and stick their noses up to normies, but also expect those same Normies to pump their bags and do all the work for them of making them finally make it. Truly profound, this subject deserves a David Attenborough documentary.

There's a bifurcation in society going on. The successful youth are WILDLY successful. Quarter million dollar total comp, buying giant houses or expensive city center houses, doing awesome. Actually on the career ladder.

subject: Oh My God
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: The thread is gripped by a pervasive sense of impending financial collapse, triggered by rapidly rising Japanese bond yields and the unwinding of the Yen carry trade. This event is perceived as a catalyst exposing global economic vulnerabilities like US government insolvency and leading to a flight to perceived safe havens, particularly precious metals, while risk assets like crypto and stocks are expected to crash.
top_quote: Fed ending QT TODAY (Dec 1st). This basically means they're going to be adding a LOT of zeroes to their balance sheet, which is another way of saying they're printing trillions of more dollar shitcoins, which will dilute the dollar even more, and make assets more expensive. Meanwhile, central banks all around the world are dumping US treasuries, including the famous Yen carry trade now being over, which helped fund US government deficit operation. Basically, the United States government is insolvent because it spends more than it collects in taxes, and there's not enough buyers for their debt. Risk assets like Bitcoin which is correlated to the Nasdaq like 50% are going to be roadkill. Gold is literally the only safe haven remaining.
